chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of nappy rash
chapter.summary: Covers the management of children with nappy rash in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth to 6 years.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I initially manage nappy rash?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Advise the parents/carers on self-management strategies.
    • Consider using a nappy with high absorbency (for example, disposable gel matrix nappies compared with non-disposable nappies).
      • Ensure the nappy fits properly (too tight increases skin occlusion; too loose minimizes absorption of fluids).
      • Parental/carer choice will depend on issues such as convenience, cost, and environmental impact.
    • Leave nappies off for as long as possible to help skin drying of the nappy area.
    • Clean the skin and change the nappy every 3–4 hours, or as soon as possible after wetting or soiling, to reduce skin exposure to urine and faeces.
      • Use water, or fragrance-free and alcohol-free baby wipes.
      • Dry gently after cleaning — avoid vigorous rubbing.
      • Bath the child daily — avoid excessive bathing (such as more than twice a day) which may dry the skin excessively.
      • Do not use soap, bubble bath, lotions, talcum powder, or topical antibiotics which can have an irritant effect.
  • Advise on sources of written information and support, such as:
    • The NHS A-Z information leaflet on Nappy rash.
    • The information leaflet on Nappy rash available on the www.patient.info website.
  • If there is mild erythema and the child is asymptomatic:
    • Advise on the use of a barrier preparation to protect the skin, which are available to buy over-the-counter.
    • Advise to apply thinly at each nappy change.
      • A range of options are available, including Zinc and Castor Oil ointment and white soft paraffin BP ointment.
  • If the rash appears inflamed and is causing discomfort:
    • For children over 1 month of age, consider prescribing topical hydrocortisone 1% cream once a day in addition, until symptoms settle or for a maximum of seven days.
      • Advise parents to apply topical hydrocortisone first and wait a few minutes before applying the barrier preparation.
      • See the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - topical (skin), nose, and eyes for more prescribing information.
  • If the rash persists and Candidal infection is suspected or confirmed on swab:
    • Advise against the use of a barrier preparation until the candidal infection has settled.
    • Prescribe a topical imidazole cream, the frequency depending on the preparation used.
      • Options include topical clotrimazole, econazole, or miconazole.
      • See the section on Topical imidazoles in Prescribing information for information on the frequency of application and duration of treatment.
  • If the rash persists and bacterial infection is suspected or confirmed on swab:
    • Prescribe oral flucloxacillin for seven days. If the child is allergic to penicillin, prescribe oral clarithromycin for seven days.
      • Adjust the choice of antibiotic if indicated, depending on swab results.
      • See the sections on Flucloxacillin and Clarithromycin in Prescribing information for more information including dosage regimens.
  • Arrange to review the child, the time interval depending on clinical judgement, to assess the response to treatment.
    • If symptoms are not settling, see the section on Treatment failure and referral for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management are largely based on a Cochrane systematic review Disposable nappies for preventing napkin dermatitis in infants [Baer et al, 2006], and expert opinion in review articles on nappy rash [Lund, 1999; Visscher, 2009; Ravanfar et al, 2012; Ness, 2013; Coughlin, 2014; Stamatas, 2014; Merrill, 2015; Atherton, 2016; Van Gysel, 2016; Cohen, 2017].

Offering advice on self-management strategies
  • The recommendations on self-management advice are largely based on expert opinion in multiple review articles [Visscher, 2009; Ravanfar et al, 2012; Ness, 2013; Coughlin, 2014; Stamatas, 2014; Merrill, 2015; Atherton, 2016; Cohen, 2017].
    • A Cochrane systematic review evaluated 17 randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and found insufficient evidence from good-quality RCTs to support or refute the use and type of disposable nappies for the prevention of nappy rash in infants. It suggested the available studies favour breathable, gel matrix nappies, however, the results should be viewed with caution as all the studies were subject to significant bias [Baer et al, 2006].
    • More recently, expert opinion in review articles state that nappies with absorbent gel material wick moisture away from the skin surface efficiently [Visscher, 2009; Coughlin, 2014]. In addition, disposable nappies aim to prevent over-hydration of the skin and maintain appropriate skin pH levels [Merrill, 2015]. Improved nappy design has resulted in an outer breathable backsheet which reduces the occlusive effect of the nappy [Atherton, 2016].
    • Baby wipes which have an acidic pH may buffer alkaline urine and restore normal skin pH, which reduces the irritant effect of urine on the skin [Atherton, 2016]. Studies have shown that using alcohol- and fragrance-free baby wipes in healthy infants results in less erythema and surface roughness compared with using water alone with a cotton washcloth or cotton wool balls [Visscher, 2009].
    • Exposing the nappy area skin to air reduces the time in contact with urine, faeces, moisture, and other irritants. It also decreases frictional damage of the skin in contact with the nappy [Merrill, 2015].
    • The recommendation to avoid soap and detergents is based on the fact that they may raise skin pH in infants which can compromise the barrier function of the epidermis [Ness, 2013].
    • The recommendation to avoid topical preparations such as talculm powder and antibiotics is based on the fact that they may cause irritant contact dermatitis and worsen the rash [Ness, 2013]. Expert opinion in a review article also notes that topical antibiotics are generally not recommended [Merrill, 2015].
Offering advice on barrier preparations
  • The recommendation to use barrier preparations is based on the fact that they provide a protective lipid film that reduces skin contact with faeces and urine, reduces humidity, and minimizes transepidermal water loss, which reduces potential skin irritation and maceration [Ravanfar et al, 2012; Ness, 2013; Coughlin, 2014; Stamatas, 2014; Merrill, 2015; Atherton, 2016; Cohen, 2017].
    • Expert opinion in a review article notes that there is a lack of evidence on the effectiveness of different barrier preparations compared with each other [Merrill, 2015].
    • Expert opinion in a review article on neonatal skin care notes that preservative-free zinc oxide ointment and petroleum-based ointments are safe and inexpensive options. Ointments are generally more effective than creams and lotions, as they provide a better moisture barrier [Ness, 2013].
    • The recommendation to apply the barrier preparation as a thin layer is based on the fact that applying a moisture barrier layer too thickly may cause water retention and worsen any skin maceration. This is supported by the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
Managing associated inflammation
  • The recommendation to consider the use of topical hydrocortisone for skin inflammation is extrapolated from expert opinion in review articles [Ravanfar et al, 2012; Coughlin, 2014; Merrill, 2015] and the British National Formulary (BNF) [BNF for Children, 2017].
    • The recommendation to use up to seven days duration of topical corticosteroid is based on expert opinion in the BNF and in a review article, as the occlusive effect of nappies may increase the risk of skin penetration and potency of corticosteroids, and increase the risk of adverse effects such as skin atrophy [Merrill, 2015]. It is also based on the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
    • The recommendation to apply any barrier preparation after the topical corticosteroid is based on expert opinion in the BNF.
Managing candidal infection
  • The recommendation to prescribe a topical imidazole if there is suspected candida infection is largely based on expert opinion in multiple review articles [Visscher, 2009; Ravanfar et al, 2012; Ness, 2013; Coughlin, 2014; Merrill, 2015; Van Gysel, 2016].
    • Expert opinion in review articles recommends to consider candidal infection in any nappy rash that fails to respond to standard treatment [Merrill, 2015] or that persists for more than three days [Coughlin, 2014; Van Gysel, 2016].
    • CKS found no good-quality evidence for the comparative effectiveness of different topical imidazole preparations for the management of nappy rash.
    • The recommendation to stop using a barrier preparation when using a topical imidazole to treat candidal infection is based on limited evidence from a US review article on infant skin care, which suggests that the rash may worsen if a water-resistant barrier preparation is used before the underlying infection is treated [Lund, 1999]. This is supported by the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
Managing bacterial infection
  • The recommendation to prescribe an oral antibiotic if there is suspected bacterial infection is largely based on expert opinion in review articles, which state that Staphylococcus aureus and streptococcus are the most likely causes of bacterial infection [Visscher, 2009; Ness, 2013; Coughlin, 2014; Merrill, 2015; Van Gysel, 2016].
    • The recommendation on the use of flucloxacillin first-line for suspected or confirmed bacterial infection is extrapolated from expert opinion in a review article [Ravanfar et al, 2012]. It is also pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice, as this antibiotic has activity against group A beta-haemolytic streptococci and Staphylococcus aureus. This approach is supported by the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
    • Topical antibiotics are not generally recommended as they may cause irritant contact dermatitis and worsen the rash [Ness, 2013].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage treatment failure?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If suspected nappy rash is not improving following initial management:

  • Consider and, if possible, manage any underlying cause of treatment failure. This may include:
    • Non-adherence to self-care advice or the treatment regimen.
    • Candidal or bacterial secondary infection — take a skin swab for culture and sensitivity, and manage accordingly. See the section on Initial management for more information.
    • An alternative cause for the rash.
    • An immunocompromised host.
  • If the rash persists following treatment for secondary infection:
    • Adjust the choice of topical imidazole or oral antibiotic if indicated, depending on swab results or
    • Seek specialist advice from a medical microbiologist, if the rash has not responded to appropriate treatment.
  • Consider referral to a paediatric dermatologist if:
    • There is uncertainty about the diagnosis.
    • The rash persists despite optimal treatment in primary care.
    • There are recurrent, severe unexplained episodes.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on treatment failure and when to refer are largely based on expert opinion in review articles on nappy rash [Ravanfar et al, 2012; Coughlin, 2014; Merrill, 2015; Van Gysel, 2016].

  • If nappy rash does not resolve with standard treatments, the child must be evaluated for underlying disease or an alternative condition [Merrill, 2015; Van Gysel, 2016].
  • The recommendation to consider seeking advice from a medical microbiologist if nappy rash does not respond to appropriate imidazole or antibiotic treatment in primary care is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
  • Further investigations such as patch testing may be helpful if there is refractory nappy rash, to exclude conditions such as allergic contact dermatitis with sensitization to specific allergens [Ravanfar et al, 2012; Coughlin, 2014; Van Gysel, 2016].
  • Nappy rash with atypical features and negative swab results may require further specialist investigations, such as skin biopsy [Van Gysel, 2016].
  • Recurrent and refractory cases of nappy rash may require systemic antifungal therapy, and if the rash is severe or chronic with erosions or ulceration, this may be a sign of underlying immunocompromise which requires further investigation [Coughlin, 2014; Van Gysel, 2016].
